matthew_1_1.text: The book of the generation of Jesus Christ. The New Testament begins with the account of Jesus Christ, and this account begins with his pedigree. This is called the book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham. Christ is called the son of David because he was the son of Mary, who was of the house and lineage of David, and Joseph also was of that royal family. He is called the son of Abraham, because Abraham was the first that received the promise of the Messiah.

matthew_1_1.text: The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham. This verse contains the title and argument of the whole Gospel. It is called the book of the generation, because it gives an account of the genealogy of Christ, and of his birth and life. Jesus Christ is here described by his names and titles. He is called Jesus, which signifies a saviour, because he came to save his people from their sins. He is called Christ, which signifies anointed, because he was anointed with the Holy Spirit above measure.

john_1_1.text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. John Gill provides an extensive commentary explaining that this verse refers to Christ as the "Word" - an eternal, divine person who existed before creation. He argues this is not about the written word, but the "essential word of God" - Jesus Christ. Gill emphasizes Christ's pre-existence, divine nature, and role in creation, citing various theological and historical sources to support his interpretation.

galatians_3_1.text: O foolish Galatians, who hath bewitched you, that ye should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth, crucified among you? Paul sharply rebukes the Galatians as "foolish" for being "bewitched" and not obeying the truth of the gospel. He reminds them that Jesus Christ was clearly portrayed as crucified among them. They received the Spirit by hearing with faith, not by works of the law. They began in the Spirit but are now trying to be perfected by the flesh. Their previous sufferings for the gospel would be in vain if they abandon its truth.

galatians_3_1.text: O foolish Galatians, who hath bewitched you, that ye should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth, crucified among you? Gill emphasizes that righteousness comes through faith in Christ, not through works of the law. He explains the law served as a "schoolmaster" to restrain transgressions, reveal sin, and point people toward Christ. The covenant promise to Abraham was about spiritual blessing through Christ, not just physical descendants. Believers are no longer under the law's strict discipline, but are "children of God by faith in Christ Jesus." Justification is not by works, but by the free grace of God, through faith in the righteousness of Christ.

galatians_4_1.text: Now I say, That the heir, as long as he is a child, differeth nothing from a servant, though he be lord of all; The Old Testament church was like a child under age, kept in darkness and bondage. When the appointed time came, God sent His Son to redeem those under the law. Believers now receive adoption as sons and the Spirit of adoption. Christians are no longer servants but sons and heirs of God through Christ.

galatians_4_1.text: Now I say, That the heir, as long as he is a child, differeth nothing from a servant, though he be lord of all; Paul uses an allegory of Abraham's two sons (Ishmael and Isaac) to illustrate the difference between the old and new covenants. The old covenant (represented by Hagar) was a "bondage" under the law. The new covenant (represented by Sarah) offers freedom through Christ. Christ was sent "in the fullness of time" to redeem those under the law. Believers are no longer servants, but children and heirs of God. The Galatians are warned against returning to "weak and beggarly elements" of the law. Spiritual children (like Isaac) are born of promise, not by natural means.
